review_blob: Well constructed beer, good aroma, lots of coffee, nice texture and mouthfeel, and the hops come through well. OTOH wasnt really impressed at how the coffee matched with the IPA profile, felt a bit like drinking two beers mixed together.

Peachy candy-like aroma. Strong bitter note on the palate with lots of hops, biscuit and caramel. Fresh hops are there but not a predominant flavour, not much by way of the floral notes I would hope for. Doesnt taste too distinct compared with the average NW stye IPA. Good quality, but dont go out of your way for it.
beer_name: Phillips Green Reaper Fresh Hop IPA

review_blob: Bottle. There is good reason this beer is hotly anticipated every year and flies off the shelves. Intense orange colour in the glass. Hops with ash/gooseberry on the nose, this is almost the best part. Taste is resiny, fresh hops, apple and pear, with a lingering bitter finish.

A well-balanced NW style IPA. For my taste the ratio of bitter to aromatic to caramel/sweet is excellent for this style of IPA. It may not be the most interesting or unconventional or interesting IPA out there, but it ticks all the right boxes and I keep finding myself buying more of it!

Another excellent special release from Lighthouse, keep them coming! 750ml purchased at Spinnakers Liquor Store in James Bay. Aroma of belgian yeasts and dark fruit (plum, cherry). Sweet and malty, with imperial stout type flavours, balanced with belgian yeast and a smooth mouthfeel. Great colour, looks beautiful in the glass.
Another tasty special release from lighthouse! Great hops flavour comes through along with abundant pilsner malts. A little too sweet but otherwise very well balanced.

This beer was excellent. Lively nose, lots of fruit. Raspberry/banana with pleasant spice and enough hops to cut through the sweetness (of which there was just perhaps a little bit too much). By far one of the better beers Ive had recently.

Pours a nice amber colour, medium head. Great noble hop flavours with nice bitterness stands out along with fairly average malt and mouthfeel. The hop flavours are the best part of this beer, as you would hope given the name. Though it is otherwise just average, the overall effect is very pleasant and I really enjoyed it. Been increasingly impressed, though never astounded, by Okanagan Spring over the past few months.
Smell is mostly caramel, beer is highly carbonated with lots of malt, some coffee and a subtle complexity. Very enjoyable, though nothing jaw-dropping.
As others have noted, definitely very malty, very English. Enjoyable enough but a little too sweet. Among the better of the basic GIB line.
beer_name: Granville Island English Bay Pale Ale

review_blob: This beer wasnt perfect, but was much better than I was expecting. Not incredibly full-bodied but not disparagingly thin, pretty good. Flavour is great, not vegetal, a little sweet but good balance with the spices and good pumpkin flavour without going overboard. Great malts, and a nice bit of hops to add some bitterness. Overall they do a way better job of balancing the "beer" aspect with the flavoured aspect of it than most flavoured beers do, making for a thoroughly enjoyable, if somewhat high on the novelty value, brew.
Slightly bland but clean tasting, refreshing hefe. Clean tasting, nice yeasts and some citrus, but flavors were quite mild. Would drink it again if offered, but probably not buy it.

Draft. Nice body, a bit, but not too thin or milky. Good coffee flavours and the fact that it is actually a lager does manage to come through. A bit too sweet perhaps, but thats probably just a matter of preference.

Enough bitterness to differentiate from an IPA, but, as others have said, just barely so. Disregarding style though; thoroughly enjoyable, would be a great session beer. Crisp and refreshing, lots of citrus, not too complex. Good but not outstanding, standard GIB fare.

Pours a dark chocolaty brown, aroma some yeast and dark fruits - flavour is really smooth, the Unibroue yeastiness is there but more subdued than in their other beers that Ive had. Malt and slight sweetness throughout, with interesting spices. Really great beer!
The classic Unibroue offering. Pours a nice gold colour, with very thin head. Aroma is mild, dominated by yeast, taste a bit spicy, lots of yeast, well balanced.

Pours a beautiful black, with a sticky tan head. Aroma is all maple syrup, very pleasant. Relatively thin body, but much better than most flavoured stouts that Ive had, and with a nice creaminess. Some interesting, if simple, malt flavours and lots of maple on the finish. The maple flavour is really great, very distinctive. This was a really pleasant surprise.

Really enjoyable and well balanced beer. Pleasant, interesting hop flavours throughout, small amount of caramel, and to me what seemed a bit like orange rind on the finish. Had at a restaurant, and would definitely buy a six-pack another time.

Aroma is apricot and a small amount of wheat, beautiful colour, strong apricot immediately on tasting, and a bit on the finish but nothing in between. Much more enjoyable paired with a good meal, the other St. Ambroise Ive had are better.
